For the funding from
the Human Security Trust Fund, the interventions will focus on Kismayo and
Afmadow, while additional co-funding from other sources (Peacebuilding Fund,
etc.) will focus on other locations within Jubaland. Members of the joint
programme currently have either an existing operational footprint or will
expand to these locations in the coming months which also supports the
feasibility of supporting interventions there.
Furthermore, all of the above referenced locations have been identified as
priority by the Federal Government Ministry of Interior and are therefore in
line with government’s current focus for the types of interventions proposed.

title: Un Joint Programme On Local Governance And Decentralized Service Delivery
description: Supporting good governance (transparency, accountability and participation) and effective and efficient management in Regional and District Councils, coupled with jump-starting social investments that accelerate the achievement of concrete results and contribute to building popular support and credibility for the nascent local government institutions constitute the broad strategy of the Joint Programme

title: International Media Support - Strategic Partnership (SPA)
description: The partnership covers strategic collaboration efforts and targeted support to three geographical programmes in Asia, Sahel and Somalia, and a series of complementary efforts through IMS Global Response programmes.

title: Shaping East African Cities as Systems to Work Better for All
description: The main research objectives are the following: 1 - To investigate formal and informal systems through which people access shelter (land, secure, tenure, housing and basic services) in each city (Hawassa, Mogadishu and Nairobi) and their relationship with deep-rooted political, economic, social and cultural conditions; 2 - To establish the ways in which low-income and vulnerable groups (including women and girls, refugees and IDPs) are positioned within systems of shelter production; 3 - To identify realisable, targeted interventions that allow low-income and vulnerable groups to improve their access to shelter by exerting greater influence on governance processes and participating in the co-production of housing, secure tenure and basic services.

programming: International Institute for Environment and Development

title: TuWezesha Akina Dada- Africa UK Young Women's Leadership and Empowerment Movement
description: Girls and young women often experience multiple forms of violence, including female genital mutilation (FGM), child marriage, domestic and sexual violence and trafficking, and yet are unable to access the needed support. This project will work with young women in Kenya, Tanzania, Somaliland and Uganda to increase confidence about their rights through leadership training and on-going mentoring support. It will also establish young women's peer networks to amplify their voices, as well as working with community leaders and policy makers to increase awareness and commitments to respect women and girls rights to be free from gender based violence.

implementing: Foundation for Women’s Health Research and Development (FORWARD)
programming: Foundation for Women’s Health Research and Development (FORWARD)

title: Teaching the Teachers
description: This project addresses the need for locally trained female teachers and teaching assistants in Galgaduud region of Somalia, which until seven years ago had no tradition of education. This organisation has already opened eight schools and runs four literacy campaigns, but the difficulties of recruiting and retaining teachers are immense. There are very few trained teachers from the area, and teachers brought in from elsewhere tend to stay for only short periods, and are exclusively male. There is a severe shortage of trained teachers in Somalia, and very few women have had the opportunity to train up to a professional standard. This particular project provides teacher training through a two year certificate course run by a local university but based in schools. This means female student teachers can live at home, making accessing the training easier. Because they are drawn from the local area, they are less likely to leave the region. The impact will be long term and educationally significant.

title: Dutch FGMC Enhancement Project
description: This proposed project on civil society support to end FGM/C is centred around the following objectives: 1) Strengthen the capacity and effectiveness of grassroots and civil society organisations working on FGM/C; 2) Create stronger and more inclusive movements to eradicate FGM/C; 3) Contribute to the global knowledge base of FGM/C; 4) Transform social norms surrounding knowledge, attitudes, and practices of FGM/C; 5) Contribute to reductions in FGM/C prevalence

implementing: Keep the Drum Lose the Knife
Kenya Council of Imams and Ulamaa
Women Initiative for Self Help Liberia Incorporated
Women's Action for Human Diginity Sierra Leone
Youth Network Against Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting
Institute for Reproductive Health & Rights Institute
Centre for Social Value and Early Childhood development
Youth Network for Community and Sustainable Development

title: Sustainable Access to clean Water,Hygiene and Sanitation to droughts affected communities in Sanaag and Sool region
description:
Sanaag and Sool regions have been facing both acute and chronic water shortages for many years. The prolonged droughts experienced in 2016/2017 have seriously affected the local communities and the water facilities too. The traditional water facilities, such as shallow wells, water pans, dams frequently dry out and there are very few boreholes-which frequently breakdown due to high demand and overuse. Badhan for instance, has a high population (89,435 people) in Eastern Sanaag, and is an old town with no permanent water sources. During the dry period, people trek more than 100km to the nearest water points, while the water prices unreasonably increase to more than 300% (Adeso internal reports). Qawlo under Taleex has similar water needs as Badhan, with an estimated population of 73,529 (UNPFA 2014 data). These 2 locations (Badhan and Qawlo) are highly populated with large rural and [pastoral population and they frequently face water shortages.  
Adeso propose to drill and equip strategic boreholes in these 2 main centers with adequate water distribution system. The project will be implemented together with the private sector, community and the government to ensure contributions from all stakeholders, the ownership and foreseeable sustainability. Our strategy is to encourage a participatory process with the key stakeholders being involved, develop local ownership and strengthen governance structure for such response. Adeso will enhance this strategy to enable value for money and high impact for this project.  The community and the private sector will contribute 20% of the total cost of Badhan borehole (that is equivalent to $40,000).
The drilling and equipping will be done through a competent local contractor, thoroughly vetted by the community, the government and Adeso technical team. Adeso will hire a water engineer, fully dedicated for this project and ensure the expected standards are met. The same contractor will do the hydro-geological survey, identify the best aquifer, present report for deliberation before moving to the actual drilling.  Adeso has strong experience in Somalia and combining hydro-geological survey and drilling into one contract will ensure smooth operation and that the contractor meets the expectation as per the contract.  Adeso will carry out, through its WASH team, an environmental and social impact analysis that may come as a result of the new borehole and apply the necessary mitigation measures in good time.  The proposed boreholes will have several distribution systems, including different water points for the livestock to avoid water contamination. 
The project will also construct latrines for the poor households, hygiene and sanitation awareness as well as strengthening the water governance structures. The ministries of water, both from Somaliland side for Talex / Qawlo site and Puntland side for Badhan will be involved to ensure the government support and also the response meet the government vision of providing adequate water to the people. 
A water ground breaking analysis will be done to determine the chemical, mineral and the biological analysis of the water.  This will be done as soon as the ground water is hit before any further work is done. The region has a history of salinity and great care needs to be taken with this, so if one aquifer fails or becomes saline, then the contractor moves to another site until the best water quality is achieved. 
Adeso is currently implementing an OFDA funded WASH project in these regions, that has mainly rehabilitation of the rural water facilities-such as shallow wells, boreholes, water pans with hygiene and sanitation components. A climate change adaption project is also being implemented in building community resilience to shocks / adaptation. Adeso recently concluded a 5 year EU Natural resource management program. These interventions provide strong complementarity to the proposed response that will result in high impact.

title: Prevention and treatment of acute Malnourished children under five years of age, pregnant and lactating women through Outpatient Therapeutic feeding Programme with stabilization center services to avert nutrition-related morbidity and mortality in Balcad, Cadale and Mahaday districts, Middle shabelle region.
description: This project is designed to provide emergency and lifesaving nutrition services to 21984 vulnerable persons (3936 men, 5204 women, 5474 boys and 7370 girls) living in Balcad, cadale and Mahaday districts of Middle Shabelle. The intervention will target pregnant and lactating women (PLW) together with children under the age of 5 years (CU5) amongst the host communities, IDPs and returnees in the Balcad district where Wocca is the primary rationalized partner in Adale where we are the secondary rationalized partner and also extend our services to Mahaday.  Wocca will operate 2 fixed/static outpatient therapeutic feeding centers (fixed OTPs) and 4 mobile outpatient therapeutic feeding programme teams (mobile OTPs) targeting 16 locations chosen on the basis of vulnerability and absence of nutrition interventions in the 3 districts. The static facilities will be established in Ceelow and Caddow Uul locations  and Cadale districts respectively while the 4 outreach teams will serve 14 locations namely Bulo Axmed Cigow, Kulmis Weyn, Buurfuule and Xudur Ciise in Mahaday Ceelka Cusub, Cisiley and Sheikh Rooble Garas weyne, Cadan gabey and Ceel Xamar in Cadale Xanlay, Muki dheere Bari, Bulo Walaal and Caro faag in Balcad. WOCCA has engaged UNICEF for backstopping during training of the project staff, community health workers (CHWs) and mothers for the “mothers MUAC approach”, on nutrition screening and case identification, Integrated management of acute malnutrition(IMAM),Infant and young child feeding education (IYCF-E) and Nutrition, health and hygiene promotion (NHHP).The trained staff shall be deployed to the targeted locations, mobile and static OTPs where together with the trained mothers will screen children under 5 and PLWs. Children under 5 with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) conditions and no medical complications will be enrolled to the static and mobile OTPs for treatment while the cases with medical complications will be referred by the mobile clinics and CHWs to the stabilization center (SC) in Waberi star village managed by WOCCA for nutrition and medical rehabilitation. Children under 5 and PLWs with MAM conditions will be referred to TSFP center managed by ARC. CHWs and Hygiene promoters will be trained on Nutrition, Health and Hygiene Promotion (NHHP), they will disseminate hygiene promotion messages to the communities to prevent outbreak and spread of communicable diseases like AWD/cholera during the activities as they move around with the mobile Team. Mothers will be counseled individually and in groups by trained nutrition staff and Community Health Workers (CHWs) on appropriate maternal infant and young child feeding as part of efforts to prevent malnutrition. The project will also provide micronutrient support by distributing multiple micronutrients (MNPs) and Vitamin A supplements to pregnant and lactating women and children under the age of 5years through the static and mobile facilities. UNICEF has been supporting WOCCA with nutrition supplies and technical guidance on previous nutrition projects within the targeted locations and currently supporting our SHF funded project running in Daynille/Kaxda IDP camps and in Balcad district. Therefore, in this project WOCCA will still engage UNICEF to provide nutrition supplies and technical support for management of SAM cases. To enhance effective coordination, WOCCA will provide monthly activity updates with partners including Nutrition cluster both regional and Nairobi level, Other agencies working in the field who are doing other sector projects in the project sites will also be updated to avoid duplication and promote effective and efficient utilization humanitarian fund.

title: Somalia: Cold Chain Equipement Optimisation Platform
description: L’équipement de la chaîne de froid (ECF) est une composante essentielle de la chaîne d’approvisionnement, qui garantit que les vaccins d’importance vitale atteignent tous les enfants. Gavi a établi la Plateforme d’optimisation de l’ECF (« la plateforme ») pour aider les pays à améliorer leurs systèmes de chaîne du froid, compléter leurs efforts afin de consolider les autres « fondamentaux » de la stratégie de la chaîne d’approvisionnement (à savoir : la mise en œuvre de plans d’amélioration continue, les données de gestion, les équipements de la chaîne du froid, le leadership avec des compétences appropriées et la conception des systèmes de la chaîne d’approvisionnement) et contribuer ainsi à l’amélioration de la couverture et de l’équité de la vaccination sur le long terme.

title: Somalia: Health System Strengthening
description: Lever les obstacles à l’amélioration de la couverture et de l’équité Lancé en 2016, le cadre de renforcement des systèmes de santé et de vaccination (RSSV) de Gavi englobe tous les types de soutien de l’Alliance. Il permet d’assurer une prévisibilité à plus long terme, une planification et une budgétisation plus intégrées des subventions, mais également de faire en sorte que les pays soient au cœur du processus décisionnel. Avoir une vue d’ensemble des différents types de soutien signifie que les futures introductions de vaccins pourront être programmées et échelonnées de façon appropriée. Les activités de renforcement des systèmes de santé sont mieux à même de renforcer la vaccination de routine et de soutenir l’introduction de nouveaux vaccins. Cette démarche nous permet par ailleurs d’évaluer les progrès accomplis par le biais d’un simple cadre de performance des subventions. Celui-ci couvre l’intégralité du portefeuille de subventions pour chaque pays, afin d’assurer le suivi des principales contributions et activités, mais aussi des résultats intermédiaires et effets escomptés. Nos investissements dans le renforcement des systèmes de santé servent pour l’essentiel à améliorer la couverture et l’équité à travers des domaines d’intervention stratégiques. Il s’agit selon nous des domaines les plus susceptibles de contribuer à des améliorations durables.

title: Somalia: Inactivated Polio Vaccine
description:
Gavi soutient la phase finale de la lutte antipoliomyélitique par l’introduction du vaccin antipoliomyélitique inactivé dans les programmes de vaccination nationaux
Afin de se joindre aux efforts de l’Initiative mondiale pour l’éradication de la polio (IMEP), Gavi met à profit son expérience en matière d’aide aux introductions de nouveaux vaccins afin de faciliter le lancement rapide du vaccin antipoliomyélitique inactivé (VPI). Les échéanciers sans précédent du Plan stratégique de l’IMEP pour l’éradication de la poliomyélite et la phase finale pourront ainsi être respectés. Gavi aide à introduire le VPI avec des fonds de l’IMEP dans les pays pouvant bénéficier de son soutien et contribue à renforcer les programmes de vaccination systématique.

title: Somalia: Pentavalent
description: GAVI’s support for new vaccines presents an opportunity for countries to not only implement vaccines that protect against diseases causing substantial morbidity and/or mortality, but also to build upon the vaccine investments in order to increase immunisation coverage rates, and strengthen routine immunisation services and primary health care systems. The pentavalent vaccine, administered in a three-dose schedule, offers protection against five diseases: diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis (DTP), heptatitis B and Haemophilius influenzae type b. Until 2013, GAVI has helped to introduce the pentavalent in 70 of the 73 GAVI-eligible countries, with the aim of reaching all 73 by the end of 2014. GAVI support for pentavalent vaccine is in line with WHO recommendations, for routine infant immunisation and primarily targeting children under one year of age.

title: PCV Immunization in humanitarian crisis settings
description: to validate the prediction from a modelling study on an effective strategy to immunize internally displaced persons in humanitarian crisis settings

implementing: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

title: The Next Economy II
description: The Next Economy is an established youth employment and entrepreneurship programme which creates jobs and opportunities for young people in challenging and fragile contexts. It enables partners in Nigeria, Mali, and Somalia in 6 locations (3 in Nigeria, 1 in Mali, 1 in Somalia, and 1 in Somaliland) to create opportunities for youth. By working with young people, business incubation hubs, employability organisations, the private sector and government, it matches youth ambitions and career goals with needs and opportunities in the labour market. It allows youth to transition from school to decent work. This project is the second stage of The Next Economy (2020-2023)

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Long-running conflict has destroyed the infrastructure of the Somali state and the country has one of the worst health indicators in the world. The high-risk groups are 2.4 million children under age 5 and more than 3 million women of child-bearing age. Ac
cording to WHO the maternal mortality ratio is 732 per 100 000 live births although most of the maternal deaths would be preventable. Rebuilding the health sector is challenged by a shortage of professional staff financial resources and effective governanc
e and NGOs have played a key role in providing with these services. African Cares Maternity Clinic and Training project has since its start in 2012 supported the development of the FinSom maternity clinic together with the local partner VMDSO. Results show
 that the service of the clinic has decreased maternal mortality rate prevalence of tetanus raised awareness about exclusive breast feeding and FGM. The clinic is well-known in Afgoye and surrounding areas and a vital source of quality maternal health care
 for both expectant mothers and the community. Hence the maternal health care services are continued also in the continuation phase of the project.The project at hand seeks to further enhance the capacity and services of the partner and the clinic so that 
eventually maternal health services could be provided without development cooperation funding. This is done by investing in the education and training of the VMDSO staff and health workers and monitoring the long-term impact of the trainings. Simultaneousl
y invaluable information on the key challenges and development needs will be mapped out and used for future trainings.  Also the support of the sexual violence victims will be intensified. It will be expanded to an in-person counselling in addition to the 
telephone support. Open-access seminars and family counselling are likewise continued and further intensified. Seminars about gender equality family planning and gender-based violence work to dismantle unequal social structures through open dialogue. Proje
ct's beneficiaries are women in labour children victims of sexual violence clinics personnel and partner organization VMDSO.

title: Sahansaho  against desertification in Somalia
description:
The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to lack of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The objective is sustainable use of natural resources and secured livelihood in the project areas. T
he project started in 2012 and it has been planned for 10 years. This continuation project will be its 4th and final phase.The outcomes of 2019-2022 will be:1. Environmental centers developed into regional hubs2. Educational institutions and trainers have 
expertise to provide environmental education3. Resilience of local communities to climate change and drought improved4. Implementation of policies related to natural resource management (NRM)The outputs will be: 1.1. Seedlings of locally successful species
 produced planted distributed and sold per year 1.2. Seed collection stands established and local availability of the seeds of the most important species secured 1.3. Operating models for the environmental centers developed 2.1. Trainers trained and traini
ng material produced 2.2. Training materials and research opportunities provided to universities and environmental education material provided to teachers 3.1. Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced in local communities 3.2. Agroforestry practices and s
oil and water conservation techniques adopted in local communities 4.1.  Network of the environmental actors built and environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated at all project sites 4.2.  Policy reviews and briefs produced for policy dialogu
e with ministries of environment and implementation of environmental policies startedThe project is implemented at 3 sites in Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil
 society in Somalia and creates new networks  that also promote peace and stability.The beneficiaries are local communities authorities and educational institutions among others.

title: Health and Education Sector Development through Skills and Knowledge Transfer in South Central Somalia
description:
The project aims at improving the capacity of public sector health and education institutions to provide quality services with special focus on vulnerable groups: women children and youth through skills and knowledge transfer by the Somali diaspora. The ov
erall objective of the project is to contribute to stabilization in South Central Somalia and Puntland through increasing access to basic services (health and education) and creating employment opportunities for the youth including women. In addition young
 Somalis will be placed in internship positions under the supervision of the diaspora experts at relevant institutions. The project trains health and education sector professionals to produce quality public services in health and education and to administe
r the resources of the sectors. The trainers are diaspora experts especially Finnish diaspora who work and share their expertise in the sectors.The Mid-Term Evaluation which was finalized in August 2018 showed that results have been gained in both health a
nd education sectors. For example the intake of patients at Yardimeli Hospital in Mogadishu has increased significantly in a short period of time from around 800 patients in July 2017 to around 4000 in March 2018. Moreover the number of assisted births inc
reased substantially. The diaspora experts placed at the Ministry of Education were successful in supporting the organizational reform and writing key strategic planning documents for the sector. According to the Mid-Term Evaluation the project was very re
levant in filling the gaps and specialized needs in the institutions. According to all participants both local and the diaspora the project was successful in producing sustainable results in skills and knowledge. The implementing partner is the Internation
al Organisation for Migration (IOM). From 2015 to 2019 Finland has supported the project with 4 420 000 EUR. From 2019 to 2021 the total budget for the second phase funded by Finland is 5 400 000 EUR. The budget is disbursed as follows: 1 MEUR in 2019; 24 
MEUR in 2020; 2 MEUR in 2021.

title: Multi-Partner Fund for Somalia (MPF)
description:
World Bank's Multi-Partner Fund (MPF) supports Somalia's stabilization and peacebuilding by strengthening Somalia's governance and the management of the state's revenues (including taxation) as well as by reviving the country's economy and the private sect
or to allow increased state revenues through taxation and to provide resources for extended and improved public services. In the project level the funded projects focus around four thematic priority areas which include government's key functions; productiv
e sectors and employment; infrastructure development; as well as management of natural resources and resilience. For example the Fund can support the payment of Somalia's government officials' salaries and improve the public financial management systems; b
oost the productivity and the value chains of potential productive sectors and improve youth employment (allowing also greater tax revenues); improve the infrastructure and therefroe improve the productivity among else in the energy sector; and strengthen 
the resilience of selected groups and professions such as cattle herders/pastoralists.The Fund also supports one of Finland's priority sectors the Health sector by strengthening health governance's salary payment and financial management systems as well as
 by supporting the governance capacity in the sector.The Fund operates in close partnership with the Federal Government of Somalia as well as with the donors and international agencies through the New Deal framework and through its aid infrastructure Somal
ia Development and Reconstruction Facility (SDRF) offering peace and statebuilding support to the Somali transition process. Finland together with other international partners has committed itself to work increasingly through the New Deal structures.Finlan
d supports the MPF over the period of 2016-2019 with 4MEUR which is disbursed as follows: 2016: 2MEUR 2018: 1MEUR 2019: 1MEUR.

title: Ramaad - environment relief project in Somalia
description:
Ramaad is a joint project coordinated by the Finnish Somalia Network  (FSN) with its partners addressing the sustainable use and management  of the natural resources in Somalia and desertification that leads to  loss of livelihoods poverty and forced migra
tion. The project started  in 2014 and is planned for 10 years. This is its 4th and final phase.  The long-term objective is sustainable use and management of natural  resources and secured livelihood in the project areas.The outcomes are:1.    3 environme
ntal centers developed into regional hubs with own income2.    Environmental education and awareness increased in project areas3.    Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced by making energy saving  stoves locally available4.    Capacity of administration
s to formulate and implement  environmental policies has increased and implementation of the  policies has startedThe main outputs are:- 30 000 seedlings of locally successful species produced planted  distributed and sold- 90 seed collection stands establ
ished and local availability of the  seeds of the most important species secured- Operating models for the 3 environmental centers developed  partners' capacity to carry out business activities built and  feasibility study for stove fabrication workshops p
repared- Environmental awareness of the local communities and environmental  education in schools increased- 3 stove manufacturing workshops established and 18 craftsmen trained- Environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated- Implementation of e
nvironmental policies at district and local level startedThe project is implemented in three areas in southern and central  Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partner NGOs  in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the ci
vil  society and enhances stability. The project areas are:1. Guriel and Dhusamareeb Galmudug2. El-Adde Gedo/Jubbaland3. Afmadow Lower Jubba/Jubbaland

title: Hiil hooyo - maternal healthcare project
description:
Hiil hooyo is a multi-actor joint project addressing maternal healthcare in Somaliland and Puntland. The key development problem is high maternal mortality having multiple negative effects. Maternal mortality rate in the project areas is one of the highest
 in the world. The project seeks to enhance women's right and the right of persons with disabilities to maternal healthcare. The project started in 2017 with a pilot phase and the new phase aims to make the results sustainable.The main outcomes are:1. Skil
ls and motivation of healthcare workers improved2. Number of mothers and children attending MCHs increased3. Attendance and accessibility of persons with disabilities to MCHs increased4. Partner universities able to conduct independently e-learning program
 in maternal healthcare and students benefitted from the developed materialThe main outputs and activities include:- 240 healthcare workers passed in-service training on maternal healthcare; 4 trainings- 10 000 persons reached by awareness raising programs
; village meetings school classes media campaigns home visits fathers clubs- 460 persons trained on the rights of persons with disabilities; training of trainers workshops- 120 university students passed e-learning program in maternal healthcare teachers t
rained and partner universities networking; e-course for students on-line training for teachers joint meetingsThe project is implemented in 10 districts in 3 areas. For the implementation the FSN has 6 NGO partners of which 3 its member organizations in Fi
nland and 5 university partners of which 2 (Diak and Xamk) in Finland. In addition the Disability Partnership Finland (DPF) offers expertize for disability issues. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil society and enhances stability.The benef
iciaries of the project include healthcare workers pregnant and breastfeeding mothers with their families persons with disabilities university lecturers and students students in secondary schools the NGO partners and indirectly communities in general in th
e project areas with an estimated population of 15 million.

title: HALO/Humanitarian Mine Action in Somalia
description:
HALOs project will support and strengthen Somalias security stability and development through humanitarian mine action and stockpile destruction. HALOs project seeks to 1) contribute to the human security and reduce civilian accidents and casualties by lim
iting the impact and proliferation of explosive items 2) contribute to the peace dividend and assist fragile communities in their own efforts to reinstate a working and stable society and 3) reduce poverty and hunger by removing blockage to high priority i
nfrastructure water access and roads. The project takes place in two phases: First completing the manual clearance of Somaliland at which point mine action in Somaliland will become completely owned funded and implemented by national authorities with suffi
cient capacity to tackle any residual tasking. Finland has supported this project since 2003. Second HALO will seek and destroy community held or abandoned stockpiles of ammunition held outside of state control across their area of operations in Southern S
omalia. The primary beneficiaries of the project are local populations in areas where HALO will conduct mine clearance and stockpile destruction. Finland will support HALOs project in Somalia during 2017-2020 with one million euros.

title: UNFPA Somalia Wellbeing of Women and Girls
description:
Support to the UN Population Fund's (UNFPA) country programme continues Finland's strong contribution for the development of Somalia's reproductive maternal and child health care services. UNFPA has been among the three UN agencies that have been involved 
in the UN Joint Nutrition and Health Programme in Somalia (JHNP) which focused on the development of maternal and child health services. Finland supported the implementation of the programme for 15.5MEUR between 2014-2016. JHNP has provided services for an
 area covering half of Somalia's population. It has reached good results having significantly contributed to the reduction of maternal and infant mortality. Through JHNP UNFPA has supported the provision of maternal sexual and reproductive health services 
as well as contributed to improving their quality. UNFPA has supported the running of 135 maternal clinics; the training of midwifes in 15 midwiferies throughout Somalia; the provision of training on reproductive health for over 600 health care professiona
ls; as well as the provision of technical assistance to the ministries of health to support their capacity building including their work on health sector strategic development. As JHNP is coming to an end in early-2017 UNFPA continues the work to develop t
he reproductive maternal and child health care in Somalia according to its mandate.UNFPA country strategy for Somalia for 2011-2016 has been extended for one year to cover also 2017. Its overall objective is to improve the wellbeing of Somali people. The c
ountry strategy aims to achieve this through reducing maternal mortality and through supporting the realization of reproductive rights and services. In addition the strategy supports gender equality and combats gender-based violence as well as strengthens 
the Somali statistical systems and promotes evidence-based planning and policy design.Three particular priority areas have been identified for 2017:1.Increased provision of comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services (around 50% of the annual bud
get for 2017)2.Promotion of gender equality and prevention of gender-based violence (around 25% of the 2017 budget)3.Strengthened national capacity on use of quality disaggregated data for evidence-based planning and policy design on population and develop
ment issues (around 25% of the 2017 budget)Finland supports the implementation of the UNFPA Somalia country strategy for 2011-2017 for 2 million euros.

title: Support project for freedom of expression journalism and public service broadcasting in Somalia
description:
The continuation phase of Vikes Somalia project supports the Somali national TV and radio channels to develop towards editorially independent public service broadcasters and assists the national journalist union to become a real trade union of media worker
s across Somalia.By providing journalist training and technical support the project seeks to 1) improve the production process and quality of news and other programmes at Somali National Television (SNTV) and Radio Mogadishu 2) improve the working conditio
ns and awareness of safety concerns among Somali journalists and 3) improve professional skills of women journalists and reduce discrimination of women journalists at the workplace.Project activities include the introduction of regular childrens programme 
production at SNTV and the construction of a new modern radio studio to replace the outdated production facilities at Radio Mogadishu. The project will support the preparation of a journalist code of conduct and the drafting of a by-law on public service b
roadcasting.More than 500 journalists across the country will be trained in labour rights practical journalism skills and professional ethics. The National Union of Somali Journalists (NUSOJ) will be assisted to set up mechanisms with media sector employer
s on how to negotiate and agree on minimum terms of employment and decent working conditions.The project is based on peer learning. Journalists are trained by more experienced Finnish and Somali journalists. Local technicians are trained by experienced Fin
nish technical experts. Local cameramen and video editors are trained by experienced visiting multimedia professionals from Finland. Experienced female journalists train local women journalists.Main cooperation partners are Somali Ministry of Information a
nd the National Union of Somali Journalists. Joint training activities will also be arranged with Somaliland Journalists Association (SOLJA) and women journalist groups.

title: Somaliland Health Sector Support (MIDA Finnsom IV)
description:
IOM MIDA Finnsom IV project focuses on contributing to improved health outcomes in Somaliland and particularly its remote regions. To achieve this the project supports the capacity of public sector institutions to provide quality health services. Three out
puts have been defined:1.) Local health professionals have skills/capacity to deliver quality health services2.) Local health training institutions have improved competence and ability to train local health professionals 3.) Ministry of Health has increase
d capacity to steer manage and coordinate the health sector The Somali diaspora experts particularly the Finnish Somali diaspora experts are the actors in the capacity building efforts. They train the local health professionals and participate in developin
g strategies plans standards and curricula for health sector. Particular attention is given to women's and child health. In the long term the project is expected to contribute to better health outcomes for Somaliland population and especially the health ou
tcomes for women and children.The first Finnish funded MIDA project was initiated already in 2008. The project has been evaluated twice and the findings suggest that the project has significantly strengthened public health institutions ability to provide q
uality services in Somaliland. The findings and recommendations of evaluations have been duly notified in the planning of the Finnsom IV phase: For example the project now focuses on the more remote regions in Somaliland where service provision is poorer t
han in the capital Hargeisa. Similarly following the recommendations the length of the assignments of diaspora experts has been increased for Phase IV.To support the implementation of the project the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) also imp
lements tailored trainings for the Ministry of Health.The duration of the Phase IV is four years from March 2017 until February 2021. The budget for the project is 4 300 000 Euros. Somalia is considered an LDC country.

title: Mustaqbaldoon
description:
The project contributes to the development problem of the vulnerability of the youth which is manifested in youth unemployment and limited access to income causing risky survival strategies such as informal quasi-legal or illegal activities and as a conseq
uence social problems like violence early sexual activity and a range of economic physical and psychological risks.The principal outcomes of the project are 1) Strengthened Civil Society and Local Administration 2) Increased motivation of youth to contribu
te to the society and 3) Increased economic empowerment of youth. The central activities include capacitating the local CSOs and public administration turning the risky survival strategies of youth to healthy ones and 3) training youth to recognize local i
ncome generation opportunities instead of leaving the country.  Developing countries own economies have generated more jobs livelihood opportunities and well-being is the priority area of Finland's development policy the project is aimed at contributing to
. Somalia is ranked as one of the bottom five countries in terms of gender inequality and therefore positive discrimination and affirmative measures will be taken to enhance the participation of young women and girls and to raise awareness about their part
icular needs. The project aims to reduce inequality by emphasizing the rights of all youth as full and equal members of the communities where they live. Project respects climate sustainability too.The project capacitates CSOs and public administration to w
ork with private sector according to multi-stakeholder approach. Helsinki Deaconess Institutes Vamos services is acknowledged in a national level as a unique concept to support vulnerable youth's access to education and employment. The same concept will be
 used together with cooperation partners Y-PEER in Hargeisa and Gedo Development in Gedo. The principal beneficiaries of the project are the youth (15-35 years) who have dropped out from education and employment.

title: Human rights based approach to strengthening community mental health services in Somaliland
description:
The project tackles Somaliland's high burden of mental health problems coupled with a weak mental health care infrastructure which is not able to provide high-quality mental health services from a human rights perspective.The project aims to increase the a
ccess of people to community-based mental health services;promote the adoption of a human rights based approach to mental health in public/private mental health services;and to increase public awareness on mental health issues to decrease the stigma and di
scrimination against people with mental disorders in Somaliland.A special focus is on women/girls and vulnerable groups (SGBV survivorsIDPsdisabled personsprisoners).To support the sustainability of the intervention and to promote the long-term development
 of the mental health care infrastructure in Somalilandthe project will increase the capacity of health care officials to promote mental health from a human rights perspective to coordinate mental health services.The main cross-cutting themes of the projec
t are:health promotionhuman rightsgender equality and good governance.The main activities are: training community mental health workers and social workers to provide community mental health servicesprovision of out-patient treatmentsupporting the capacity 
of the MOH to plan and implement mental health services and policyand raising awareness on mental health.The main beneficiaries of the project are people in Somaliland suffering from mental disorderstheir families and communitiesvulnerable groups in need o
f mental health care civil society and health officials.PSR is well positioned to carry out the project with 30+ years of experience in health development projects also of mental health projects in post-conflict contexts.PSR has long-term project experienc
e in Somalia/Somaliland (2006-) and good local networks.The local partner GAVO is a well-respected local NGO with long-term experience in mental health projects.The Finnish partners FiPSR and Disability Partnership Finland have long-term experience that co
ntributes closely to the project.The project contributes to the FSA project in Jubaland and collaborates with the HDI project in Somaliland

title: Fighting TB in Somalia: public-private partnerships and inclusive communities
description:
The project is founded on PSR's previous projects in Somalia which have developed new strategies to tackle tuberculosis (TB)  especially in community and private sector engagement. A special focus will be placed on women and vulnerable community members: d
isabled persons IDPs and prisoners. Tuberculosis is a central health problem in Somalia. The increase of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a global threat  fighting against MDR-TB in Somalia benefits all countries. Another central problem is th
e low treatment coverage rate of about 37% leaving far too many cases untreated further transmitting tuberculosis to others. The impact targets of the project are to: a) tackle multi-drug resistant tuberculosis; and b) increase the tuberculosis case detect
ion rate. The long-term objective of the project is to contribute to the reduction of the tuberculosis burden in Somalia with the following means:1. Increase the access of women and vulnerable groups to TB services (such as disabled personsIDPs and prisone
rs)2. Increase TB referrals from the private sector3. Improve the quality of TB treatment in both the public and private sector4. Improve the quality of TB laboratory work.The central partners of the project are the National Tuberculosis Programmes of Soma
liland and Somalia. PSR has a central role in developing the national tuberculosis diagnostic infrastructure in Somalia. The project will support the National TB Reference Laboratories in Somaliland and South-Central Somalia as well as will treatment of tu
berculosis patients in 3 clinics in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. These clinics will develop innovative community public and private sector engagement models to increase case detection improve treatment quality and to increase public awareness and decrease stigm
a/discrimination. The clinics will also provide HIV services and nutritional support for malnourished patients (with WFP).Together with the local administration the tuberculosis clinics will be transformed into health centers providing specialized tubercul
osis services by the end of 2022 to support integration with basic health services and sustainability after the project has ended.

title: CO Somalia 2016-2020 CIVSAM
description: ***MISSING VALUE Global Objective***

title: GECPD Social & Economic Justice 2016-2020
description:
In Puntland pastoralism, fishing and trading, are the three main economic activities. They are highly complementary and interdependent, and constitute the basis of the present economy. However, poverty rate in Somalia is amongst the highest in the world. It affects 60% of the population in urban households and over 95% of the population in rural households. 
Puntland is host to an estimated 149,000 IDPs, refugees and asylum seekers and insecurity is the major cause of displacement, followed by drought and the lack of livelihood opportunities. Access to land and water continue to be the primary challenges for host communities and IDP, as well as forced relocation for IDP. Limited livelihoods make it difficult for Somalis to cope with environmental or political shocks. For children, Somalia has been characterized as one of the most challenging countries to grow up in. Only 29% of the children in Somalia attend primary school, and only 7% of the secondary school-age population attends secondary school. Poverty is one of the main reasons why children are sent out to work instead of going to school. In addition, about 33% of girls compared to 21% of boys had to work at home instead of attending school.
The partner, Galkayo Education Center for Peace and Development (GECPD), will implement the project in Harfo District, Mudug Region, Puntland Stateand will work in;
Decent Work: Collection of data and development of Somalia country profiles for decent work in fragile contexts; Advocacy on development of coherent labour laws;  Advocacy for guidelines on abolishment of child labour; Training and advocacy on establishment of cooperatives and unions. 
Women Economic Empowerment: Mapping of market needs and opportunities for women; Value chain analysis and private sector development for increased employment opportunities, specifically targeting women; Support to income generating activities, in particular targeting women, youth and IDPs; Entrepreneurship support, in particular for women and youth
The actors with the most significant impact on the programme and also those that will be most affected by the programme, include right holders (women, men, youth, IDP and other marginalized groups) CSOs, government bodies, private sector, religious and traditional leaders, local businesses/private sector.

implementing: Galkayo Education Center for Peace and Development

title: Competence Development Somalia 2016-2020 CIVSAM
description: ***MISSING VALUE Global Objective***

title: POHRD Capacity Strengthening 2017-2020
description:
Puntland Offce of Human Rights Defender advices and engages Puntland Government and parliament at all levels since the central authority and responsibility for protecting human rights rests with the government. The office has also other role to engage and capacitate the government, civil societies, right holders and other related stakeholders to respect, protect and fulfill human rights requirements in accordance with the constitution, national laws, Paris principles and other ratified conventions by Somali State. 
The project goal is to enhance the organizational effectiveness and independence by promoting and protecting human rights standards and mechanisms at individual, community, and State levels.By Ensuring collective framework for effective partnership engagement in the promotion and protection of human rights efforts; and Expanding access of justice service in all Puntland regions through establishment of physical offices and complaint response mechanisms for protection of human rights

implementing: Puntland Office of Human Rights Defender

title: SPHEIR Prepared for Practice
description: PfP is addressing Somaliland’s health workforce crisis by transforming health education, putting practice-orientated learning, teaching and assessment at its centre. By the end of the project, there will be a new generation of prepared-for-practice graduates better able to meet the needs of the Somaliland health sector. MedicineAfrica acts as the technology partner on this project. MedicineAfrica runs and administer an online platform to facilitate distance learning. We also advice and consult on enhancing the e/learning experience for tutors and students along with supporting in various other project area.

title: Political accommodation and reconciliation in Somalia (CDI-SOYDEN-Forum ARC)
description: Conflict Dynamics International (Conflict Dynamics) leads the implementing consortium in partnership with the Somali Youth Development Network (SOYDEN) and the Forum of Federations (FoF). The program of work described below aims to deliver significant impact towards the following ARC sub-goals: - 1.2 Formal and informal authorities responsible to maintain security perform their tasks more effectively, more accountably and in better coordination, responding to the needs and rights of the population - 1.3 Communities and civil society lead efforts to improved human security independently and in coordination with responsible authorities By contributing to a lessening of conflict at the local level, and supporting governance structures that effectively prevent and mitigate conflict the program of work is also expected, though the creation of an enabling environment, to make a contribution towards other ARC goals, in particular: - 3.1 National and international actors take responsibility for effective and inclusive mechanisms for peacebuilding and prevention of conflict, with an active role for women - 3.2 Government institutions at all levels implement laws and policies and have functioning mechanisms in place for internal and external accountability The program of work comprises two complimentary approaches to lessening of conflict at the local level and supporting governance structures that effectively mitigate conflict: - Program Outcome A focuses on addressing local level human security challenges faced by communities across Somalia as a result of an incomplete reconciliation process by creating and supporting inclusive local level peace architecture. - Program Outcome B focuses on supporting the Federal Government and Federal Member States in reaching consensus on, and beginning to implement, an accommodating distribution of powers as part of the process of creating a federal Somalia.

title: Integrating Sexual and Reproductive Health Services in Bosaso
description: The programme through a contribution to Médecins du Monde-France aims at improving access to sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services for the population of Bosaso (Puntland, Somalia). This will be done through progressively integrating the SRH into existing primary health care services offered in health facilities. Regional health authorities as well as local health providers are closely involved in the intervention to not only ensure that services are culturally responsive but also that they become an integral part of the health system.

title: Integrating Sexual and Reproductive Health Services in Bosaso

Regional health authorities as well as local health providers are closely involved in the intervention to not only ensure that services are culturally responsive but also that they become an integral part of the health system.

title: Institutionalizing Healthcare Sector Development Through Temporary Returns of Somali Diaspora Health Professionals (MIDA FINNSOM IV: Somaliland)
description: This phase of  the project will promote and enhance the active role of qualified Somali diaspora experts in contributing to improving health outcomes in Somaliland. The proposed project aims at contributing to improved health outcomes in Somaliland, in particular in relation to maternal and child health. To achieve this, the project is expected to improve the capacity of public sector health institutions in Somaliland to provide quality healthcare services. The main partner of this intervention will be the Ministry of Health (MoH) of Somaliland. The objectives of this project are aligned with all major local government strategies and policies, such as the Somali/and Health Policy (2nd edition), Health Sector Strategic Plan II and Somali/and National Development Plan.

title: Somalia Stabilization Initiative
description: IOM will engage with the relevant local stakeholders, in prioritized geographic areas, in an effort to address the growing multidimensional challenges threatening stability in the country. IOM will pro-actively seek opportunities to empower local and regional administrations to respond to the strategic needs of their communities, and improve governance by strengthening ties between communities, local actors, and Somali government authorities, and catalyze the stabilization process.

title: Improving access to water and sanitation in Somalia
description: Improving access to water and sanitation services in urban and rural areas of Somalia and contributing to the reduction of infant and under-5mortality caused by WASH related diseases in Somalia.

title: Improving access to water and sanitation in Somalia
description: The project will address the urgent needs of water and sanitation service delivery in rural and peri-urban areas affected by recurrent drought and waterborne diseases such as acute watery diarrhea and cholera.

title: Improving access to water and sanitation in Somalia
description: The project will address the urgent needs of water and sanitation service delivery in rural and peri-urban areas affected by recurrent drought and waterborne diseases such as acute watery diarrhea and cholera.

title: Achieving local solutions to displacement crises in Somalia: a human security approach to durable solutions
description: The project takes a human security approach to enable and empower communities and local leadership to identify the localized, multidimensional and multi-sectoral factors impacting their security; the drivers of conflict and displacement; and the capacities and strengths of the community. They will also be capacitated to discuss, plan, implement and monitor activities aimed at addressing all dimensions of human insecurity.

title: Stabilization Support in Fragile Areas of Somalia
description: The project will provide rapid stabilization and early recovery support in target urban and peri-urban areas in Somalia. It is intended to serve as a bridge between more immediate responses in areas impacted by conflict, extremism and also displacement and longer-term development interventions. The project entails sequenced interventions that look at simultaneously building the capacity of caretaker administrators in the target localities, facilitating inclusive community processes, and generating information and context analysis to support community engagement processes, inform government stakeholders and facilitate adaptive programme management.

title: Leveraging the Strength of Women in Somalia to Mitigate Conflict-Related Sexual Violence (CRSV) and Prevent Violent Extremism (PVE)
description: This project leverages IOM’s existing partnerships with line ministries and women-led civil society organizations in Somalia to address a critical gap in providing direct support to survivors of conflict related sexual violence systematically committed by Al-Shabaab (AS) as a tactic of war. Specifically, this project supports women formerly associated with AS and the communities of return to reduce their vulnerabilities and improve their overall human security, using human-centric and prevention-oriented approaches.

title: Daryeel: Stabilisation Support to Fragile Areas of Somalia II
description: This project contributes to stability and peace by creating conditions for restoring trust horizontally between communities, and vertically between communities and local leadership in Somalia, aiming at rebuilding the social contract between Somali citizens and state institutions and providing a bridge to longer-term development interventions. Derived from experience on the ground, IOM identifies four pathways for addressing the most urgent stabilization needs in Somalia: implementing a dynamic pre- and post-recovery stabilization toolkit; facilitating ‘government-led, community-driven’ action planning; enabling civic engagement in the absence of robust governance structures; and scaling-up grassroots inter-communal mediation efforts.

title: Stabilization Amplification Mechanism
description: This project aims to contribute to stability and peace in Somalia by creating conditions for restoring trust horizontally, between communities, and vertically, between communities and local leadership. Building on lessons learned from previous IOM projects in Somalia, this project's interventions incorporate years of best practices to deliver the Organization's integrated stabilization strategy, which is optimized by a combination of local presence/access, multi-sectoral expertise, and nuanced contextual acumen. The ultimate goal is to support the rebuilding of the social contract between Somali citizens and State institutions and providing a bridge to longer-term development interventions.

title: Help, Protective, prevention measures
description: Help, protection, prevention and cooperation activities in Somalia 2016 - 2018

title: Pre-positioning Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Emergency Supplies and Equipment in the Lower Juba and Middle Juba Regions of Somalia
description: The proposed project will support timely and effective humanitarian response in Lower and Middle Juba regions in South Sudan through prepositioning of water sanitation and hygiene (WASH) emergency supplies and equipment such as soap, jerry cans, aqua tabs and pumps in key strategic locations to enhance existing response mechanism. The project will target affected populations through the regional supply hubs (RSHs) in Kismayo and Dhobley in order to respond to emergencies in a timely manner. The overall coordination will be led by the WASH Cluster at the central, regional and district levels, and the stock management will be supervised directly by IOM field staff in cooperation with the regional Lower and Middle Juba WASH Cluster.

title: Facilitating Safe Movements and Sustainable Reintegration of Somali Returnees from Yemen
description: IOM continues to facilitate safe and dignified movements and sustainable reintegration of Somali returnees from Yemen, particularly women and unaccompanied minor children. In particular, through this project, IOM aims at: (1) supporting and assisting Somali returnees with registration assistance, facilitation of exit visa issuance and fit to travel assessment; (2) improving government institutions' organizational and technical capacity to facilitate the successful reception and reintegration of returnees; and (3) providing support to the selected communities of return in order to ensure a more conducive reintegration of returnees in Somalia.

title: Integrated Humanitarian and Stabilization Support Towards Improved Human Security in Somalia
description: In this project, IOM aims to improve human security of migrants, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and communities of return in Somalia through the provision of integrated life-saving and stabilization support. In particular, IOM works on ensuring that affected populations have dignified, safe and secure living conditions with basic services through Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), Health and Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) interventions. In addition, IOM provides returnees with medical and psychosocial support and livelihood assistance through individual and community rehabilitation projects.

title: Emergency Drought Response Through Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) and Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Item (SNFI) Response in Gedo and Bay Regions, Somalia
description: In order to address the acute needs of drought-affected displaced and vulnerable Somalis, IOM aims at improving access to services and ensure dignified living conditions through camp coordination and camp management and emergency shelter and non-food items (NFI) response in Gedo and Bay regions in Somalia. In particular, IOM will improve internally displaced persons (IDP) living conditions through site development, extensions of existing sites and relocation of IDPs. In addition, IOM will cover critical gaps identified by the Shelter and NFI cluster through cash-based interventions and in-kind emergency shelter distribution.

title: Multi-Partner Trust Fund (MPTF) - Unterstützung Somalia
description: Support of election process in Somalia 2016 and for creation of federal state. Support of UN Department of Safety and Security (Multi-Partner Trust Fund (MPTF))

title: Provision of Integrated Multi-Sectoral Assistance to Vulnerable Dsiplaced Populaions in Somalia
description: Through this project, IOM seeks to address the acute needs of displaced and vulnerable persons in Somalia through camp coordination and camp management, water, sanitation and hygiene, health and nutrition assistance. In particular, due to the deteriorating drought conditions, IOM is deploying emergency medical services and ensuring safe access to services through camp coordination and camp management, including strengthening communications with the communities and improving living conditions through site development and maintenance. Similarly, IOM conducts health and hygiene promotion as well as provides emergency temporary access to safe water through cash-based interventions and operating and maintaining water supply systems. In addition, IOM's Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) continues to collect internally displaced persons information on movement and needs, as well as site assessments.

title: Kismayo-Baidoa Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Project
description: The project objective contributes to improved quality of life, inclusiveness and resilience through the provision of sustainable water supply and sanitation services. The project focuses on increasing access to safe water, improved sanitation and strengthening capacity for improved delivery of water and sanitation services in Kismayo (Jubbaland State) and Baidoa (South West State) towns. The project aims to reduce economic and social exclusion of poor and vulnerable groups in the two towns, where an estimated 65 per cent of the population live below the basic needs poverty line and 70 per cent of the population is younger than 30 years and often unemployed by improving access to safe and reliable water supply.

title: Promotion of Human Security through Comprehensive Health and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Assistance to Crisis and Conflict-Affected Populations in Somalia
description: The proposed project provides an integrated multi-sectoral life-saving and stabilization support towards improved human security of migrants, internally displaced persons and communities of return in Somalia. IOM is contributing to dignified, safe and secure living conditions and access to basic services for vulnerable populations affected by human-made and natural disasters. Through this project, IOM also works towards ensuring that vulnerable populations affected by crisis in Somalia have increased access to health services, and will ensure that targeted affected populations with high risk acute water diarrhoea/ cholera have improved access to safe water and good hygiene practices.

title: Improving Living Conditions of Conflict and Climate Affected Populations in Somalia
description: IOM provides a coordinated response to ensure an effective provision of life-saving shelter and non-food items (NFI) support to affected populations. This will be done through the procurement of 500 NFI emergency kits and 500 shelter kits (In-Kind) for the contingency stock managed by IOM, which will allow Shelter and NFI Cluster partners to respond to emergencies in a timely fashion. The intervention will include support to partners for transportation and distribution costs. Furthermore, IOM will use a Cash-Based Intervention (CBI) modality to support an additional 2,500 households to purchase shelter and NFI items in locations where the markets are functioning. In addition, IOM will contribute to improved access to basic services and protection for affected populations through improved humanitarian coordination and site management. The intervention will encompass both the production and dissemination of relevant surveys to humanitarian partners, the monitoring of population flows in targeted locations in Somalia, internally displaced persons site management activities and capacity building for local camp coordination and camp management cluster partners.

title: Emergency Flood Response in Somalia by Providing Access to Clean Safe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Services in Gedo, Mudug and Bari Regions
description: IOM is providing an integrated water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) response in three regions of Somalia of which the specific districts are key hot spot areas and are currently categorized as areas of high and/or very high vulnerability due to the flooding in the country. The proposed WASH activities specifically focus on supporting displaced people and people at risk of acute watery diarrhea/cholera and also include support to crisis-affected host-communities.

title: Emergency Flood-Response Through Provision of Emergency Shelter in Gedo Region
description: In order to address the acute needs of flood-affected displaced and vulnerable Somalis in Gedo region, IOM proposes to ensure dignified living conditions through an emergency shelter response. 2,000 HHs (12,000 individuals) will receive emergency shelter support through cash-based intervention.

title: Anticipatory Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Actions to Prevent and Reduce Human Suffering, Through Provision of Clean Safe Water and Hygiene Promotion Services
description: IOM is ensuring sustainable access to clean water and preventative hygiene services for Somali communities living in districts affected by COVID-19, locusts, and flooding. Activities include the rehabilitation and upgrading of existing boreholes and shallow wells, water treatment and provision of water treatment products, and hygiene promotion.

title: Coordinated Humanitarian Assistance To Climate and Conflict Affected Populations in Somalia
description: Displacement as a result of drought, flooding and conflict continues to be a coping mechanism within Somalia as people crowd into cities and towns in search of humanitarian services. Through this project, IOM proposes a comprehensive response to contribute to dignified, safe and secure living conditions and access to basic services for vulnerable populations affected by man-made and natural disasters. This is through integrated interventions in four areas of work: shelter and non-food item, camp coordination and camp management and Displacement Tracking Matrix, health and water, sanitation and hygiene.

title: Provision of Integrated Multi-sectoral Assistance to Vulnerable Displaced Populations in Somalia
description: The project provides a comprehensive response to contribute to dignified, safe and secure living conditions and access to basic services for vulnerable populations affected by man-made and natural disasters. This will be done through integrated interventions in improved access to basic services and protection for affected populations through improved humanitarian coordination and site management; improved health and nutrition outcomes for vulnerable populations; provision of sustained water, sanitation and hygiene services and promotion of hygiene to communities affected by recurrent climatic events; and the provision of shelter and non-food item to communities in dire need of support.

title: Disaster Risk Reduction for Kismayo IDP Sites at Risk of Flooding
description: This project aims at developing structural flood mitigation measures by establishing, rehabilitating and enhancing drainage systems in internally displaced persons (IDP) sites in Kismayo, Somalia, to increase the capacity of IDP communities to respond to future shocks and threats. IOM will also train community leaders, including women groups on camp coordination and camp management modalities, flood mitigation and response.

title: Integrated Support for Displacement Affected Populations in Baidoa, Somalia
description: The objective of this project is to ensure that internally displaced persons at risk of eviction in Baidoa, Somalia, have dignified, safe and secure living space and access to services. It aims to address immediate humanitarian needs and risk of eviction, whilst contributing to urban development and city extension, including land tenure security.

title: Realization of Human Security by Improving Living Conditions of Crisis Affected Communities and Building Their Resilience in Somalia
description: The project intends to respond to immediate humanitarian needs and improve living conditions of internally displaced persons, as well as build resilience of the crisis affected population. This project approach ensures immediate life-saving activities through humanitarian response, whilst strengthening the resilience to subsequent shocks such as floods but also recurrent drought conditions, ensuring communities are prepared to cope with shocks, thereby reducing the re-emergence of instability driving factors that can reverse the recovery progress already achieved in those regions. Through the preparedness, response and resilience angle, the project aims to contribute to linking humanitarian support to development, ensuring long-term sustainable solutions for communities at risk of natural disasters.

title: Anticipatory Action on Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) to Prevent and Reduce Human Suffering, through Provision of Clean Safe Water and Hygiene Promotion Services
description: Through this project, IOM aims to sustain access to clean water and preventative hygiene services for communities in Somalia that living in districts that are expected to be negatively impacted by the anticipated drought shock, due to lack of water and structures for personal and domestic hygiene.

title: Emergency Drought Response through Provision of Temporary Clean Safe Water, Hygiene Promotion, Sanitation and Health Care Services
description: This project contributes to the objective of improved access to safe water and health care services to save lives, alleviate suffering and avert further displacement among drought affected populations in Lower Juba, Gedo, Mudug and Sanaag regions in Somalia. This is done through providing immediate access to safe and clean water through water trucking and hygiene promotion activities, as well as providing essential life-saving primary health-care services.

title: Multi-Sectoral Support to Communities Affected by Conflict and Natural Hazards
description: Since the collapse of the Somali central government in 1991, Somalia has suffered a highly complex protracted conflict characterized by changing political dynamics and power shifts. Although there have been improvements to the peace and security situation in Somalia since the formation of the Federal Government of Somalia in 2012, the overall situation remains fragile with Al-Shabab a major obstacle to peace and security. Forced displacement remains an ongoing a reality for people living in Somalia due to armed conflict, environmental hardships due to climate change, combined with inadequate resource distribution that is often exacerbated by clan based, ideological differences and land and natural resources competition. The COVID-19 pandemic has added yet another hazard that people in Somalia face. While it has now been over a year since the first case was detected in Somalia and efforts have been made to mitigate the risk, the situation is always evolving. With the main objective to ensure dignified, safe and secure living conditions and basic services for vulnerable populations affected by conflict and disasters in Somalia, IOM proposes an integrated camp coordination and camp management, Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) and shelter and non-food item emergency support.

title: Enhancing Conditions for Durable Solutions for Internally Displaced Persons (lDPs) and Returning Refugees in Somalia
description: This programme will be delivered through a consortium approach of IOM (lead), Concern and the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), with the Regional Durable Solutions Secretariat (ReDSS) supporting a learning andknowledge management component. The proposed programme will focus on: (1) Strengthening government leadership and capacity to enable durable solutions processes at Federal Member States (FMS)/Banadir Regional Authority (BRA) and district levels; (2) Enabling targeted displacement affected communities to increase decision making and increase access to basics services; (3) Increasing self-reliance of displacement affected communities through inclusive, sustainable economic opportunities; and (4) Ensuring that durable solutions programming and decision making processes at national and regional levels are informed by knowledge and evidence generated by the programme.

title: Hilfs- und Schutzmaßnahmen für Binnenvertriebene und Flüchtlinge
description: Humanitäre Hilfs- und Schutzmaßnahmen für Binnenvertriebene in Somalia und somalische Flüchtlinge in Nachbarländern (Dschibuti, Äthiopien).

unclassified: Reg. Südl. Afrika - Ostafrika n.a. (nur ODA-Länder)

title: Dhulka Nabaada (The Land of Peace): Supporting Land Reform in Somalia
description: This project supports four federal member states in Somalia with land reform initiatives and the integration of land dispute resolution mechanisms. Through high-level capacity building and policy development support, this project strengthens the institutional structures needed to address pressing land issues across Somalia. The project also facilitates and provides support to state and community-led initiatives to promote and provide training on peaceful conflict transformation and rights protection.

title: Midnimo II (Unity) - Support for the Attainment of Durable Solutions in Areas Impacted by Displacement and Returns in Galmudug and Hirshabelle States
description: This project capitalizes on the success of a prior project phase and builds on momentum for state/district expansion of authority and accountability to respond to challenges relating to conflict, displacement and community cohesion in Somalia. The engagement intends to capacitate state-led and community driven processes and solutions pertaining to conflict prevention, land dispute resolution, service delivery and durable solutions for displaced persons in areas of displacement and return. This includes a mixture of policy development support, institution building, trainings to officials and community members and the direct provision of goods and services.

title: Enhancing Peace and Security Measures in Somalia through Support for the National Programme on Disengaged Combatants
description: The overall objective of this project is to foster peace and stability by supporting the Government of Somalia to effectively rehabilitate and reintegrate disengaged combatants and women formerly associated with Al-Shabaab. To achieve this objective, long-term change is sought through the achievement of the primary outcome: enhanced implementation of the national programme leading to the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of disengaged combatants and women formerly associated with Al-Shabaab.

title: Mediation in order to resolve the Galkayo conflict
description: ​Beitrag zur Staatenbildung durch Mediation und Dialog zur Lösung des Konflikts in Galkayo, Somalia

title: Improving stability through weapons management in South Central Somalia
description: The project will include the following activities - construction of 6 armouries and the provision of appropriate storekeeper and armoury manager training in Kismayo. Armoury compliance assessments across 26 past infrastructure interventions funded by the German Government.

title: Leveraging the Strength of Women in Peace-Building by Promoting Safe and Sustainable Integration of Women Formerly Associated with Al-Shabaab (AS)
description: The overall objective of the project is to contribute to Somalia’s women, peace and security efforts and the Government of Somalia's ownership of the National Programme, leading to successful gender-sensitive rehabilitation and reintegration of women formerly associated with Al-Shabaab.

title: Enhancing Human and Operational Capacities of Somalia’s Immigration Authorities III
